node.title: Why Victoria's still recording hundreds more daily COVID-19 cases than NSW
node.alt: The Melbourne city skyline, looking over trams and the Princes Bridge.
node.description: While Victoria and New South Wales's daily tallies are still hundreds of cases apart, those watching the numbers closely say the shape of their infection curve largely tells the same story.
node.content:
["If you're living in Victoria, odds are you've gotten those texts or messages from friends and relatives interstate.", "Perhaps on a day like Thursday, when this week cases spiked above 1,400, prompting them to reach out in concern.", "\"Oh no, that sucks. Fingers crossed for you, hope it gets better soon\",\u00a0or words to that effect.", "Maybe they've asked you, why is it that New South Wales has cases so low while Victoria's are still so high?", "But when you step back, both states have actually followed a fairly similar trajectory since their lockdowns eased.", "The key difference?", "When Sydney left its lockdown behind on October 11, the state reported 496 new infections.", "When Melbourne exited its lockdown ten days later, Victoria reported 2,189 new cases.", "Since then, the seven-day average for new infections in both states has dropped, before stabilising into a plateau.", "Matt Hopcraft, an associate professor at the University of Melbourne and expert in dental public health, has been watching the figures closely for months.", "\"Clearly we've had a reduction in cases here in Victoria from where we were at the peak, and New South Wales saw the same,\" he said.", "\"I think the fundamental thing that we're seeing is we reopened at a much higher number of cases.", "\"When they reopened, they were at a lower number of cases.\"", "Victoria's current caseload puts it on the lower end of the Burnet Institute's modelling, which underpinned the state's path out of lockdown.", "Dr Hopcraft said the effective reproduction number appeared to have stabilised at around one in both states, resulting in NSW plateauing at a seven-day average a little above 220 cases, and Victoria's around 1,100.", "
Widely spread outbreaks made Victoria's containment tricky
", "Deakin University's chair of epidemiology, Catherine Bennett, agreed the volume of cases when the two states reopened was a large part of the equation.", "\"But more than that, it's more widely spread in Victoria,\" she said.", "\"New South Wales \u2026\u00a0had a series of outbreaks they had to deal with, you know, Albury, up on the Central Coast and so on.", "\"We don't have a particular outbreak that we need to focus on and contain in Victoria,\u00a0it's actually been quite widespread and that's been a bit more of a challenge.\"", "She said the spread of cases across Victoria as the state aimed to reopen also meant the vaccination push had to be widely focused to help protect dispersed communities facing outbreaks.", "An interstate comparison of hospitalisations is a bit more complicated, as the two states use different metrics.", "But again, trends are not dissimilar:\u00a0Victoria's hospitalisations have begun to dip below 300 towards the end of this week, while New South Wales's hospitalisations fell to 140 on Friday.", "\"I don't think it's a matter of what's going wrong in Victoria, I think things are going right,\" Dr Hopcraft said.", "He said while case numbers were not as low as people may want and there was still pressure on the healthcare system, a willingness from Victorians to keep up the mask-wearing and restrictions still in place was a good sign.", "Professor Bennett said the stability in Victoria's numbers was \"amazing\" considering how light-touch restrictions had become.", "\"You're likely to see that balancing now between not needing restrictions to hold your case numbers, they don't take off because you've got a great vaccination rate,\" she said.", "
Omicron's a wildcard, but summer could help push cases down a little more
", "Both Dr Hopcraft and Professor Bennett noted it remained to be seen how the new Omicron variant would affect things.", "But Professor Bennett was broadly optimistic that summer's combination of a break on unvaccinated children mixing in classrooms and more outdoor events could even see cases \"drift down\" a little and hold in Victoria.", "\"As we start to roll out the booster program, particularly for the older people who are a bit more at risk of that serious illness on infection, then we should be in a good position,\" she said.", "Professor Bennett said just how much the state could drive cases down over the Christmas break would depend on every individual.", "\"Knowing that you can choose to wear masks, whether you're asked to or not, or you can have your Christmas either outdoors or with all the windows open,\" she said.", "\"If you're just that bit mindful this year, all those things are going to just make that bit of difference \u2026 that then will impact on what we see statewide.\""]
